results.title: These Apes Dance Like Someone Is Watching
results.abstract: Gibbons move with rhythm and intention. Dare we say style?

results.title: Three Medical Practices That Older Patients Should Question
results.abstract: Some treatments and procedures become routine despite lacking strong evidence to show that they’re beneficial. Recent studies have called a few  into question.

results.title: Missouri Bird Flu Case Raises Prospect of Human Transmission
results.abstract: A close contact of someone with bird flu became ill on the same day, the C.D.C. reported. But the second person was not tested, and the cause of the illness is unknown.
results.byline: By Apoorva Mandavilli and Emily Anthes
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

results.title: W.H.O. Authorizes Mpox Vaccine, Clearing Way for Use in Africa
results.abstract: The decision is a crucial step in getting shots to the Democratic Republic of Congo, the center of the outbreak.

multimedia.caption: The Jynneos vaccine, made by Bavarian Nordic, has been approved in Europe as well as the United States and other high-income countries since a global mpox outbreak in 2022.
The Jynneos vaccine, made by Bavarian Nordic, has been approved in Europe as well as the United States and other high-income countries since a global mpox outbreak in 2022.

results.title: Boar’s Head Shuts Down Virginia Plant Tied to Listeria Deaths
results.abstract: The company said that the site would close indefinitely and that it would permanently stop making liverwurst. Union officials said the plant’s 500 workers would be given severance and offered relocation.
results.byline: By Christina Jewett and Teddy Rosenbluth

multimedia.caption: Boar’s Head announced that it would close the plant in Jarratt, Va., indefinitely.
Boar’s Head announced that it would close the plant in Jarratt, Va., indefinitely.
Boar’s Head announced that it would close the plant in Jarratt, Va., indefinitely.

results.title: The Big City Is Vibrant. Birds There Might Be Getting Less So.
results.abstract: Recent studies show that certain feather pigments can help neutralize toxic pollution. It means darker, duller birds could have a survival advantage.

multimedia.caption: Great tits, a common species in Europe, that were part of a study on urban birds in Malmo, Sweden.
Great tits, a common species in Europe, that were part of a study on urban birds in Malmo, Sweden.

results.title: This Chatbot Pulls People Away From Conspiracy Theories
results.abstract: In a new study, many people doubted or abandoned false beliefs after a short conversation with the DebunkBot.

multimedia.caption: Buzz Aldrin, left, and Neil Armstrong practiced during a rehearsal for the moon landing in April 1969. One conspiracy theory holds that the event was staged.
Buzz Aldrin, left, and Neil Armstrong practiced during a rehearsal for the moon landing in April 1969. One conspiracy theory holds that the event was staged.

results.title: Elevated Lead Levels Found in One-Third of Cinnamon Samples
results.abstract: Consumer Reports found lead in a variety of products, at a time when federal regulators are seeking authority from Congress to combat the problem of heavy metals in foods.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: Cinnamon products identified by the Food and Drug Administration in March as having high levels of lead.
Cinnamon products identified by the Food and Drug Administration in March as having high levels of lead.

results.title: New Look at Landslide Potential Shows 44% of U.S. Is at Risk
results.abstract: A new federal database helps users determine the likelihood of their community experiencing a landslide.

results.title: Adderall in Higher Doses May Raise Psychosis Risk, Study Says
results.abstract: New research suggests that dosage plays a role in a rare side effect of A.D.H.D. stimulants.

results.title: Lloyd Kaufman, Who Saw Answers Behind the ‘Moon Illusion,’ Dies at 97
results.abstract: He advanced the study of a millenniums-old mystery: why the moon appears larger on the horizon than it does high in the night sky.

multimedia.caption: Prof. Lloyd Kaufman, left, and Dr. Irvin Rock with optical equipment they created to help explain why the moon appears larger on the horizon than it does when overhead. They were on a terrace at Yeshiva University in Manhattan in 1960.
multimedia.copyright: Carl T. Gossett/The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Prof. Lloyd Kaufman, left, and Dr. Irvin Rock with optical equipment they created to help explain why the moon appears larger on the horizon than it does when overhead. They were on a terrace at Yeshiva University in Manhattan in 1960.

results.title: Dr. Chatbot Will See You Now
results.abstract: Americans are already turning to A.I. for health information in large numbers, new research suggests.

multimedia.caption: About one in six adults use A.I. chatbots for medical advice at least once a month, a recent survey found.

results.abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris nodded to the urgency of climate change but also highlighted the country’s record levels of oil and gas production.

results.title: The ‘Country Doctor’ Who Upended Our Understanding of Dementia
results.abstract: Francisco Lopera defied rebels, cartels and vampire bats to become a pioneering researcher of Alzheimer’s disease.

results.title: Cholera Deaths Soar Worldwide Despite Being Easily Preventable
results.abstract: Fatalities spiked 71 percent last year, far outpacing the 13 percent rise in cases, the World Health Organization said.

multimedia.caption: A patient in an isolation tent being treated for cholera last year in Malawi. The spread of the disease there was driven by catastrophic weather events.
A patient in an isolation tent being treated for cholera last year in Malawi. The spread of the disease there was driven by catastrophic weather events.

results.title: Polaris Dawn Astronauts Reach Record High Orbit Above Earth
results.abstract: After launching early on Tuesday, the billionaire Jared Isaacman and his crew traveled to altitudes not visited by any astronaut since the Apollo moon missions of the 1960s and ’70s.

multimedia.caption: A view from SpaceX’s Crew Dragon Skywalker spacewalk platform released on Tuesday.
A view from SpaceX’s Crew Dragon Skywalker spacewalk platform released on Tuesday.

results.title: Francisco Lopera, Pioneer in Alzheimer’s Research, Dies at 73
results.abstract: A neurologist in Colombia, he worked with the world’s largest extended family with Alzheimer’s and helped fuel research to prevent or delay dementia symptoms.

multimedia.caption: Dr. Francisco Lopera in 2019. He identified about 6,000 members of a large extended family in Colombia, about 1,200 of whom were born with a genetic mutation that causes Alzheimer’s.
multimedia.copyright: Federico Rios Escobar for The New York Times

results.title: Those Keurig Coffee Pods? They’re Not So Recyclable, the S.E.C. Says.
results.abstract: The agency said Keurig, in its financial filings, had claimed its pods could be “effectively recycled” but didn’t note that two big recycling companies wouldn’t accept them.

multimedia.caption: There has been a long debate over the environmental effects of single-serving coffee and tea pods.
There has been a long debate over the environmental effects of single-serving coffee and tea pods.
There has been a long debate over the environmental effects of single-serving coffee and tea pods.

results.title: ‘Imminent Threat’ Found at Boar’s Head Plant 2 Years Before Fatal Listeria Outbreak
results.abstract: U.S. inspectors listed serious problems in 2022 that could have resulted in strict measures like a pause in production. But the plant continued operating, and some conditions persisted.
results.byline: By Christina Jewett and Teddy Rosenbluth
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: The Boar’s Head plant in Jarratt, Va. has been closed indefinitely while the company and federal authorities investigate the cause of the listeria outbreak.
The Boar’s Head plant in Jarratt, Va. has been closed indefinitely while the company and federal authorities investigate the cause of the listeria outbreak.

results.title: Doctors Give Black Women Unneeded C-Sections to Fill Operating Rooms, Study Suggests
results.abstract: Healthy Black women with low risk factors were far more likely to get C-sections than white women with similar medical histories, a large new study found.

multimedia.caption: About 30 percent of babies in the United States are delivered via C-section, about double the proportion deemed appropriate by the World Health Organization.
About 30 percent of babies in the United States are delivered via C-section, about double the proportion deemed appropriate by the World Health Organization.

results.title: Polaris Dawn Astronauts Launch on Ambitious Private Mission
results.abstract: The mission is taking people farther from Earth than anyone has traveled since the end of NASA’s Apollo moon missions.

results.abstract: Patients received “substantial” payments, their lawyers said, and the clinic agreed to staffing changes.

results.title: Teen Girls’ Brains Aged Rapidly During Pandemic, Study Finds
results.abstract: Neuroimaging found girls experienced cortical thinning far faster than boys did during the first year of Covid lockdowns.
org_facet: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

multimedia.caption: The thinning of the cortex is seen by scientists as the brain rewiring itself as it matures.
